bug.author: Arnoques
bug.summary: Documentation of medianBlur does not mention borderType
bug.description:
<denchmark-h:h5>System information (version)</denchmark-h>
OpenCV => 2.4.9.1 Operating System / Platform => xubuntu Compiler => no idea
<denchmark-h:h5>Detailed description</denchmark-h>
The documentation for medianBlur (<denchmark-link:http://docs.opencv.org/2.4/modules/imgproc/doc/filtering.html?highlight=median#cv2.medianBlur>http://docs.opencv.org/2.4/modules/imgproc/doc/filtering.html?highlight=median#cv2.medianBlur</denchmark-link> ) fails to mention what happens to the borders. I think this is important because a first glance through the docs led me to believe that it would use . After noticing this is not the case, it took me a while to find the correct answer in the source. In the case I was interested in, it uses ( ) Please update the docs to include this. I know it's a detail, but it's the kind of detail good documentation should tell. <denchmark-h:h5>Steps to reproduce</denchmark-h>
from numpy import * import cv2
orig = arange(7*8).reshape((7,8)).astype(uint8) cvmedian = cv2.medianBlur(orig, 7)
data_portion = orig[:4, :4].copy() border_default = cv2.copyMakeBorder(data_portion,3,0,3,0,cv2.BORDER_DEFAULT) assert(median(border_default) != cvmedian[0,0])
border_replicate = cv2.copyMakeBorder(data_portion,3,0,3,0,cv2.BORDER_REPLICATE) assert(median(border_replicate) == cvmedian[0,0])

comments.comment: Euhm, since the function is not even requiring a border handling parameter, why it is important to mention this. I think from a general point of view, adding a comment about border handling will make it more complex for users if it is not a configurable parameter. Oh and BTW why use 2.4 docs? Any specific reason not to use the <denchmark-link:http://docs.opencv.org/master/d4/d86/group__imgproc__filter.html#ga564869aa33e58769b4469101aac458f9>latest 3.x docs</denchmark-link> ?

Oh and BTW why use 2.4 docs? Any specific reason not to use the latest 3.x docs?
No reason... I didn't notice it was a different one when I sent the link. I think it's important to mention it because even if it's not a choice the user has, it was a choice that the writer of the code did make, and it affects the results. In my specific case, I was modifying a function that used cv2.medianBlur and extracted just a single pixel from it. I wanted to replace the function with np.median of the area around the pixel to make it faster, and noticed it didn't give me the same results near the border (pretty much like in the code above). After trying to find the reason in the docs, I had to find the source and understand it (at least a little) to find the way to solve this problem. It took me a while since my C++ is close to non-existent. If there was a short mention of this in the docs, all of that would've been much faster.
Submitted a documentation fix with the suggested mention. Lets see how the devs are considering this.
